legal.title: Legal Protection
legal.description: This section provides simplified legal guidance to understand hate speech, documentation, reporting methods, and freedom of expression limits.

modal.evidenceNote: Ensure you keep evidence (screenshots, links) before reporting. Some platforms may request additional information.

hateSpeechContent.definitionText: Any form of expression that incites violence, discrimination or hostility against individuals or groups based on their identity:
hateSpeechContent.keyElementsText: Hate speech must include incitement or call to violence/discrimination, not just expression of opposing opinion.

crimeAssessment.title: When is content considered a crime?
crimeAssessment.intro: Content is evaluated in context, based on its nature, intent, and potential impact.

clearCrime.title: Clear Crime
clearCrime.conclusion: This content exceeds freedom of speech limits.

hateSpeechContent.whatWeMonitorIntro: We focus our legal monitoring on content that exceeds the limits of opinion and expression, and constitutes an actual danger or direct incitement against individuals or groups, including:
whatWeMonitor: Explicit or implicit calls for extermination or collective violence
Systematic incitement to harm a specific group
Spreading intentional misinformation to cause harm or incitement
Serious threats targeting people or groups based on their identity
hateSpeechContent.whatWeMonitorConclusion: These cases are evaluated according to context, apparent intent, and likelihood of harm.
hateSpeechContent.whatWeDoNotTitle: What is not subject to legal follow-up?
hateSpeechContent.whatWeDoNotIntro: The following cases do not fall within the initiative's legal monitoring scope:
whatWeDoNot: Personal disputes or individual conflicts not related to hate speech
Individual insults or abuse that do not involve incitement or threats
Non-public content or private messages posing no public danger
Reports lacking evidence, a reliable link, or clear context
hateSpeechContent.whatWeDoNotConclusion: In these cases, reporting via platforms or seeking non-legal avenues may be advised.
hateSpeechContent.differenceTitle: Hate Speech vs. Freedom of Expression
hateSpeechContent.differenceIntro: We believe that protecting freedom of expression is a fundamental condition for any democratic society, but it is not absolute when it turns into a tool for harm or incitement.
hateSpeechContent.protectedIntro: Includes, but is not limited to:
protectedItems: Objective criticism of ideas, beliefs, or ideologies
Expressing opposing political or social opinions
Constructive critique of public policies and practices
Academic, research, and professional media discussion
notProtectedItems: Incites violence against a specific group
Calls for discrimination or exclusion based on identity
Defames a group or dehumanizes them
Uses false information to incite hostility or hatred
hateSpeechContent.boundaryText: Freedom of expression ends when incitement to hatred or violence begins. You can criticize ideas and policies, but incitement against people or groups based on their identity is not permissible.

documentationContent.screenshotIntro: A screenshot is the primary piece of evidence in any report. It must contain complete information to prove the violation and preserve the context.
documentationContent.mustIncludeTitle: What a valid screenshot must include
mustInclude: the full text of the offending content
the account or page name clearly visible
profile picture of the content publisher
mistakes: cutting part of the text or removing context
taking the screenshot after the post is deleted
failing to save the original post link
documentationContent.proTipText: Always take a full-page screenshot rather than cropping a portion. Full context increases credibility and legal admissibility.
documentationContent.archivingIntro: In addition to the screenshot, use archiving tools to create a permanent version of the content.

archiveTools.name: Perma.cc
archiveTools.description: Permanent link creation for webpage content

archivingSteps: Copy the link of the violating post
Open one of the archiving tools listed above
Paste the link into the archive submission field
Save the archive link generated afterward
Attach the archive link along with your report
securityTips: keep multiple backups in separate locations
record the date and time each file is saved
documentationContent.retentionText: keep evidence for at least one year from the reporting date, as it may be needed for legal follow-up or appeal.
quickTips: document immediately ‚Äî content may be deleted
take multiple screenshots from different scroll points
save comment sections if relevant to context
record screen-video if the content is animated

reportingContent.title: Reporting Mechanism

guide.intro: The reporting path for hate speech or incitement varies depending on where the instigator lives and the nature of the published content. Some cases can be handled through in-platform reporting tools, while others require legal documentation or referral to competent authorities.

steps.title: Identify the content type
steps.desc: Check whether the content includes incitement to violence, threats, dehumanization, or targeted hate speech.

steps.title: Identify the instigator's location
steps.desc: Determine if the person is inside Syria, in an EU country, or elsewhere; this defines the possible legal path.

steps.title: Preserve digital evidence
steps.desc: Keep the post link, publication date, and a clear screenshot without resharing the content.

steps.title: Choose the legal reporting path based on the instigator's residency
Use reporting tools inside social platforms
Avoid direct contact or engagement with the offender

guide.conclusion: These steps help you report responsibly, reduce the spread of hate speech, and increase accountability.

reportingContent.decisionIntro: The reporting path depends on the instigator's country of residence and the nature of the content. Choose the most appropriate option below.

insideSyria.title: Reporting via Official Authorities
insideSyria.scope: Jurisdiction: Receiving reports related to crimes
insideSyria.method: Method: Submitting an official report personally or via a lawyer
insideSyria.alert: Procedural Alert: Keep a copy of the report and reference number for follow-up.

outsideSyria.title: Reporting in Residence Countries
outsideSyria.desc: If you reside outside your country, you can report according to the host country's laws. Competent authorities vary by country.
outsideSyria.action: Go to the Applicable Laws section to select the country and view the competent authority.

platforms.title: Reporting via Digital Platforms
platforms.desc: Platform reporting tools can be used to remove content violating terms of use.
platforms.warning: Important: Reporting via platforms does not replace legal reporting in dangerous cases.

highRisk.title: How do we handle high-risk reports?
highRisk.intro: In cases involving actual danger, we follow an internal path aimed at rapid assessment and appropriate guidance.

limitations.title: Role Limitations
limitations.text: Baligh initiative does not provide legal representation or handle litigation. Our role is limited to analyzing reports, providing non-binding initial guidance, and directing individuals to competent authorities or independent lawyers when necessary.

lawsContent.title: Legal Frameworks for Combating Hate Speech
lawsContent.description: Legal frameworks for combating hate speech vary from country to country, but most states criminalize incitement to violence or hatred against individuals or groups based on protected characteristics.
lawsContent.sectionInfo: Legal Guidance: In this section, we provide guiding legal information to help you understand the laws and competent authorities in each country.
lawsContent.mapInstruction: üó∫Ô∏è Select a country to view applicable laws and reporting authorities.

faqContent.checklistTitle: Conditions for a Valid Legal Report

checklist.title: Public Content
checklist.desc: The post must be publicly available and not in a private message.

checklist.title: Complete Evidence
checklist.desc: Ensure the original link, clear screenshot, and publication date are available.

checklist.title: Clear Incitement
checklist.desc: The content must clearly incite violence or discrimination and not be just an opposing opinion.

faqs.q: Is this report considered an official legal document?
faqs.a: The report is a 'documentary proof' based on legal standards, and serves as strong supporting evidence. However, submitting it to judicial authorities requires a formal procedure by you (or your lawyer) with the competent authority.

faqs.q: Is my data legally protected when using the tool?
faqs.a: Yes, the tool is designed to protect the reporter's identity. Your data is not shared with any third party, and the issued report does not include your personal name unless you manually add it for documentation purposes.

faqs.q: Does this report replace hiring a lawyer?
faqs.a: No, this report is a tool to strengthen your legal file and save research time, but it does not replace direct legal advice in complex criminal cases.

faqContent.helpText: Our legal team can help you assess complex cases

protection.title: Digital Protection ‚Äì How to Protect Yourself from Hate Speech?
protection.subtitle: This section offers practical tools to protect yourself digitally, understand how hate speech spreads, and our shared role in countering it.

awareness.title: üß† Understand & Analyze - Hate Speech Awareness
awareness.intro: Before you can protect yourself, you must understand how hate is built and how it spreads. This section helps you develop a 'critical eye' to detect harmful speech before you are affected by it.

timeline.title: üîç Observe how hate is built... so you can stop it
timeline.intro: Hate speech doesn't appear suddenly; it goes through three clear stages:

1.title: Dehumanization & Preparation
1.desc: Small words are used to dehumanize the other: 'insects', 'germs', 'traitors'... simple words but they prepare the ground for accepting violence.

2.title: Media Justification
2.desc: This language is recycled through media pages or influential accounts, turning into 'legitimate' or 'socially acceptable' speech.

3.title: Rapid Spread & Contagion
3.desc: It spreads via hashtags, memes, short videos, and fake accounts, reaching a wide audience that repeats it unconsciously.

timeline.tip: üí° Tip: When you understand these stages, recognizing harmful speech becomes an automatic step that helps you stop it and not engage in it.

checklist.title: ‚ùì Analyze content before interacting with it
checklist.intro: When viewing a post regarding a group, sect, or region, use this quick filter to determine its nature:

questions.0: Does it target identity? (Instead of individual action)
questions.1: Does it include dehumanization or insults?
questions.2: Does it drive you to fear or anger instead of understanding?
questions.3: Does it generalize to a whole group based on an individual act?
questions.4: Does it use inflammatory or violent language?

results.high: üö® High Probability - This is likely hate speech

checklist.contextAlert: ‚ö†Ô∏è Clear warning sign in Syrian context: Much content starts with a normal sentence and ends with a complete generalization: 'All Druze...', 'All Sunnis...', 'Alawites always...'. This jump from individual to group is a strong indicator of hate speech.

misinfo.title: üõë Avoid falling for misinformation that creates hate
misinfo.intro: Before sharing any post, pay attention to four mechanisms used daily to create sectarian and regional narratives:

framing.name: Framing
framing.def: When a story is presented from only one angle to reach a predetermined conclusion.
framing.ex: Showing one incident to represent the 'nature' of an entire group

generalization.name: Generalization
generalization.def: When an individual's action (one incident) turns into 'group traits' or a characteristic of an entire region.
generalization.ex: 'All people of region X are...' based on one person's act

halfTruth.name: Half-Truth
halfTruth.def: When content presents correct information but hides the rest of the context to create a misleading and inflammatory narrative.
halfTruth.ex: Mentioning part of the event and hiding the full context

echoChambers.name: Echo Chambers
echoChambers.def: When the platform shows you content that resembles your convictions only, making you feel that 'everyone' thinks like you.
echoChambers.ex: In Syria, echo chambers are responsible for creating waves of collective anger that amplify rumors

misinfo.tip: üí° Remember: When you recognize these patterns, deconstructing hateful speech becomes easier than resharing it.

responsibility.intro: Digital protection is not just about protecting yourself, but about protecting others and building a safe digital space for everyone.

protectOthers.title: ü§ù Contribute to protecting others from targeting
protectOthers.intro: When you see someone targeted by sectarian, gender, or regional speech, do not leave them alone:

support.title: Immediate Support
support.desc: One word of support breaks the psychological impact of abuse. Contact the targeted person and tell them you stand with them.

reporting.desc: Multiple reports on the same content reduce its spread and increase speed of removal from the platform.

protectOthers.note: üí° Remember: Hate speech often targets the most vulnerable groups in society. Solidarity is not a symbolic act, but direct protection that prevents language from turning into action, and contributes to building a safe digital space for everyone.

bystander.title: üó£Ô∏è Don't be just a 'bystander': You are part of the narrative
bystander.intro: Silence in the face of hate speech means allowing it to continue. Always choose a small action:

stop.desc: Don't share harmful content even if your goal is to condemn

warn.desc: Alert your circle about misinformation and rumors

positive.desc: Share stories of cooperation between Syrians

bystander.note: üí° Remind others that words create fears, and also create trust. In a fragile context like Syria, every linguistic choice affects civil peace more than we imagine.

safeSpace.intro: Digital protection is not just about what you don't do, but what you choose to do:
safeSpace.create: Create content that replaces fear with understanding
safeSpace.quote: Hate spreads fast because it relies on instant reactions. Countering hate relies on slow and deep awareness: awareness that starts from one user... and can change the whole space.

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.subtitle: Answers to the most frequently asked questions about the initiative and how it works

items.a: The Baligh Initiative is a civic-tech project aimed at monitoring and combating violence and hate speech in the Syrian digital space. The initiative relies on combining automated text analysis with human review, and is based on research and legal expertise to provide accurate content classification and reliable reporting services.

Analysis begins with an AI model trained on Syrian dialects and context to determine the severity of the speech. In complex or sensitive cases, a specialized team reviews the results to ensure accuracy and minimize bias. This dual approach combines the speed of technology with the expertise of specialists.

items.q: Is my data safe when using the tool?
items.a: Yes. The initiative stores input texts to improve monitoring and analysis accuracy, without linking them to users or their identities. Data related to reports is stored with high privacy measures and used exclusively for legal and research purposes related to combating hate speech.

items.q: How can I report offensive content?
items.a: After analyzing the text, the classification result is shown to the user. If the content contains hate speech or dangerous incitement, a legal report can be generated according to the laws of the chosen country, whether inside or outside Syria. Reports are sent to competent authorities or can be downloaded and used directly in the reporting process.

items.q: What is hate speech? And how do we distinguish it from freedom of expression?
items.a: Hate speech is expression that targets an individual or group based on their religious, sectarian, gender, or regional identity, and is based on incitement, stigmatization, or dehumanization. Freedom of expression remains protected unless it turns into incitement or collective abuse. This distinction helps protect public debate without normalizing verbal violence.

items.q: Does the analysis rely entirely on AI?
items.a: No. AI is an assisting tool, not the final arbiter. The model performs the initial classification, while sensitive cases are reviewed by humans to ensure higher accuracy in understanding the context, language, and narratives prevalent in Syrian discourse.

items.q: What should I do if I think the system made a mistake?
items.a: You can submit a request for manual review. The text and context are re-read, and the classification is corrected if an error is proven. This process aims to build user trust and continuously develop the system.

items.q: What happens after submitting a formal report?
items.a: A legal report is generated containing the violating text, risk level analysis, and the legal basis related to the chosen country. It is then forwarded to the initiative's partners or downloaded directly by the user for use in reporting to competent authorities.

items.q: Do I need to create an account?
items.a: No. Everyone can use the analysis tool without registration. An account becomes useful for those who wish to save a record of reports or track them.

items.q: Can the tool be used for research or educational purposes?
items.a: Yes. The tool is used in training programs, research on digital media and civil peace, and in building anti-hate speech curricula. The initiative can provide technical or methodological support to interested parties.

items.q: Is the tool only for Syrians?
items.a: Although the tool is specifically developed for Syrian dialects and narratives, its use is available to anyone who wishes to understand hate speech in Arabic or monitor incitement patterns in similar contexts.

items.q: What type of content cannot be analyzed currently?
items.a: The system cannot analyze non-textual images, long videos, or audio recordings. Work is underway to add OCR and audio processing tools to expand the scope of analysis in the future.

items.q: Why should hate speech be reported?
items.a: Because hate speech is not just words, but a precursor to violence and division. Numerous experiences in conflict countries have shown that ignoring this speech leads to mass crimes and threatens civil peace. Reporting is a preventive practice aimed at protecting society and promoting accountability.

items.q: What should I do if I receive a direct threat?
items.a: It is advised to save full evidence (text, link, date), analyze the content via the tool, generate a legal report, and then inform competent authorities in the country of residence. You can also contact the initiative for technical or guidance support.

The initiative operates within a wide cooperation network including lawyers inside and outside Syria, civil society organizations, media institutions, and researchers in digital rights fields, allowing it to combine legal expertise, technical capability, and research knowledge in a comprehensive approach to hate speech.

items.q: How can I join or volunteer?
items.a: You can contact us via the 'Join Us' page. The initiative welcomes volunteers in the fields of monitoring, research, design, translation, and legal analysis.

items.q: Is the initiative a political entity?
items.a: No. The initiative is completely independent and does not belong to any political or partisan entity. Its goal is to curb hate speech, promote citizenship values, and build a safe and responsible digital space.
